content.title: Pacemaker Basics
content.summary: Permanent pacemakers are implantable devices that deliver electrical stimuli to the heart to treat bradyarrhythmias. Understanding pacemaker nomenclature (NBG code), indications, mode selection, and basic troubleshooting is essential for all physicians caring for patients with implanted cardiac devices.
key_points: DDD: Dual chamber sensing and pacing with tracking - most physiologic for AV block
VVI: Ventricular pacing/sensing - for chronic AFib with slow ventricular response
AAI: Atrial pacing - for sinus node dysfunction with intact AV conduction
Rate response (R): Sensor-driven rate increase for chronotropic incompetence
Pacemaker syndrome: Loss of AV synchrony with VVI pacing; treat with upgrade to DDD
content.statement: Pacemaker selection requires matching device mode to underlying conduction abnormality, with dual-chamber pacing preferred for most indications to maintain AV synchrony.

explanation.intuition: Think of a pacemaker as a 'backup drummer' for your heart's natural rhythm. When the heart's electrical system fails to keep time (bradycardia), the pacemaker steps in. The mode code tells you WHERE it's helping (atrium, ventricle, or both), WHAT it's listening for (intrinsic beats), and HOW it responds (pace when needed, inhibit when not).
explanation.key_insight: AV SYNCHRONY is crucial for cardiac output. The atrial 'kick' contributes 15-25% of ventricular filling. VVI pacing (ventricle only) causes loss of AV synchrony and can reduce cardiac output by 10-20%, causing 'pacemaker syndrome' with fatigue, dyspnea, and hypotension. DDD pacing preserves synchrony.
explanation.technical_details: Modern leads use bipolar sensing (less interference) and steroid-eluting tips (lower pacing thresholds). Lead impedance 200-1200 ohms is normal; high suggests lead fracture, low suggests insulation break. Sensing amplitude: atrial >2mV, ventricular >5mV. Pacing threshold <1V at 0.5ms pulse width is ideal.

definitions_glossary.pacemaker: Implantable device delivering electrical stimuli to maintain adequate heart rate
definitions_glossary.NBG_code: NASPE/BPEG Generic 5-letter code describing pacemaker function
definitions_glossary.DDD: Dual chamber pace/sense with AV tracking; most physiologic mode
definitions_glossary.VVI: Ventricular pace/sense with inhibition; used in chronic AFib
definitions_glossary.AAI: Atrial pace/sense with inhibition; for sick sinus with intact AV node
definitions_glossary.rate_response: Sensor-driven rate modulation for chronotropic incompetence
definitions_glossary.AV_delay: Programmed interval between atrial and ventricular pacing
definitions_glossary.sensing: Detection of intrinsic cardiac electrical activity
definitions_glossary.capture: Successful depolarization of myocardium from pacemaker stimulus
definitions_glossary.undersensing: Failure to detect intrinsic activity; inappropriate pacing
definitions_glossary.oversensing: Inappropriate inhibition from detecting non-cardiac signals
definitions_glossary.pacemaker_syndrome: Symptoms from loss of AV synchrony with ventricular-only pacing

pathophysiology.mechanism: Pacemakers sense intrinsic cardiac activity and deliver appropriately timed electrical stimuli when intrinsic rate falls below programmed threshold

DDD.function: Senses and paces both chambers; tracks atrial activity to pace ventricle

VVI.disadvantage: No AV synchrony; risk pacemaker syndrome if in sinus rhythm

indications: Sinus node dysfunction with intact AV conduction

class_I_indications: Sinus pause >3 seconds or HR <40 with symptoms
Symptomatic Mobitz Type II second-degree AV block
class_II_indications: Asymptomatic complete heart block with escape <40 or asystole >3s
Sinus node dysfunction with HR <40 without correlation

troubleshooting.failure_to_capture: Increase output, check lead position, rule out MI/metabolic
troubleshooting.failure_to_sense: Increase sensitivity, check lead, rule out undersensing
troubleshooting.oversensing: Decrease sensitivity, check for EMI, rule out lead issues

definition.@value: The fundamental principles of permanent cardiac pacemakers including nomenclature, mode selection, indications, and basic troubleshooting

scopeNote.@value: Covers pacemaker modes, indications, and common programming considerations

learning_objectives: Interpret the NBG pacemaker code including all 5 positions
Match pacemaker mode to underlying conduction abnormality
Identify Class I indications for permanent pacing
Recognize and troubleshoot common pacemaker malfunctions
Explain pacemaker syndrome and its treatment
clinical_pearls: DDD = most physiologic; maintains AV synchrony (atrial kick)
VVI only for chronic AFib - causes pacemaker syndrome in sinus rhythm
Rate response (R) for chronotropic incompetence (can't increase HR with exercise)
Magnet over pacemaker = asynchronous mode (DOO/VOO) - useful for EMI
Lead impedance: high = fracture; low = insulation break
common_misconceptions: All pacemaker patients need VVI - DDD preferred for most
Pacemakers always pace - they sense and inhibit when intrinsic rate adequate
MRI always contraindicated - MR-conditional pacemakers now common
